So drye and ſtonie, that a thouſand ſhowres
From theſe two eyes, continually rayning,
Could never ripen.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Y'ave conquer'd me:
I did not thinke to yield, but make me now,
Even what you will my Lelia, ſo I may
Be but ſo truly happy to enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: No, no, thoſe fond imaginations,
Are dead and buried in me, let 'em reſt.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I'le marry you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: The Devill thou wilt Iulio
How that word waken'd me? come hither friend,
Thou art a foole, looke ſtedfaſtly upon her
Though ſhe be all that I know excellent
As ſhe appeares, though I could fight for her,
And run through fire; though I am ſtarke mad too
Never to be recover'd, though I would
Give all I had l'th world to lye with her
Even to my naked ſoule, I am ſo far gone,
Yet me thinks ſtill we ſhould not doate away
That that is ſomething more then ours, our honours
I would not have thee marry her by no meanes,
Yet I ſhould do ſo; is ſhe not a whore?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: She is; But ſuch a one—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Tis true, ſhe's excellent,
And when I well conſider, Iulio
I ſee no reaſon we ſhould be confin'd
In our affections; when all creatures elſe
Enjoy ſtil where they like.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And ſo will I then,

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: He's faſt enough I hope now, if I hold him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You muſt not do ſo though, now I conſider
Better what 'tis.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Do not conſider Angilo,
For I muſt do it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No I'le kill thee firſt.
I love thee ſo well that the wormes ſhall have thee
Before this woman, friend.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I was your counſell.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: As I was a knave,
Not as I lov'd thee.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: All this is loſt upon me Angilo,
For I muſt have her: I will marry yee
When you pleaſe; pray looke better on me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay then no more friend; farewell Iulio,
I have ſo much diſcretion left me yet
To know, and tell thee thou art miſerable.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Stay thou art more then ſhe, and now I finde it.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Is he ſo?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: No, I'le ſee thee ſterv'd firſt. Exit Lel.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Friend.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Fly her as I do, Iulio, ſhe's a witch.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Beate me away then, I ſhall grow heere ſtill elſe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: That were the way to have me grow there with thee
Farewell for ever. Exit Ang.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Stay, I am uncharm'd,
Farewell thou curſed houſe, from this houre be
More hated of me then a Leproſie. Exit Iulio.

sp.speaker: Lelia.
sp.l: Both gon? a plague upon 'em both,
Am I deceiv'd againe? Oh I would raile
And follow 'em; but I feare the ſpight of people,
'Till I have emptied all my gall; the next
I ſeize upon, ſhall pay their follies
To the laſt penny; This will worke me worſe
He that comes next, by heav'n ſhall feele their curſe. Exit.

div.head: Scaena quinta.
div.stage: Enter Iacamo at one doore Fabritio at another.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: O yee are a ſweet youth, ſo uncivilly
To rayle and run away?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: O are you there Sir?
I am glad I have found ye, you have not now your Ladies
To ſhew your wit before.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Thou woult not, woult 'a?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What a ſweet youth I am, as you have made me,
You ſhall know preſently.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Put up your ſword
I have ſeene it often, 'tis a Fox.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: It is ſo,
And you ſhall feele it too; will you diſpatch Sir?
And leave your mirth out? or I ſhall take occaſion
To beate ye, and diſgrace you too.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Well ſince, there is no other way to deale with you
Let's ſee your ſword, I am ſure you ſcorne all odds,
I will fight with you —

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How now? they meaſure, and Fab: get his Sword.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Nay ſtand out,
Or by this light I'le make yee.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: This is ſcurvy
And out of feare done.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: No Sir out of judgement,
For he that deales with thee, thou'rt growne ſo boyſtrous
Muſt have more wits, or more lives then another,
Or alwayes be in Armor, or inchanted;
Or he is miſerable.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Your end of this Sir?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: My end is only mirth to laugh at thee,
Which now I'le do in ſafety; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Shart? then I am growne ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Thou art,
And wilt be ſhortly ſport for little children,
If thou continueſt this rude ſtubborneneſſe.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O God, for any thing that had an edge?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Fye, what a ſhame it is,
To have a lubber ſhew his teeth?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Why doſt thou laugh at me thou wretched fellow?
Speake with a pox; and looke ye render me
Iuſt ſuch a reaſon —

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I ſhall dye with laughing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: As no man can finde fault with: I ſhall have
Another Sword; I ſhall ye fleering puppy.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Does not this teſtineſs ſhew finely in thee?
Once more take heed of children, if they finde thee
They'le breake up ſchoole, to beare thee company,
Thou wilt be ſuch a paſtime, and whoo'te at thee:
And call thee bloody bones, and Spade, and Spitfire,
And Gaffer Madman; and go by Ieronimo,
And will with wiſpe and come aloft, and crack rope,
And old Saint Dennis with the dudgeon Codpeeece:
And twenty ſuch names.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No I thinke they will not.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Yes but they will: and Nurſes ſtill their children
Onely with thee, and ●ere take him Iacanio.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Gods pretious, That I were but over thee
One Steeple height: I would fall and breake thy neck.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: This is the reaſon I laugh at thee,
And while thou art thus, will do: tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I wonder how thou durſt thus queſtion me,
Pre'thee reſtore my Sword.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Tell me but one thing,
And it may be I will: Nay Sir; keep out

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Well I will be your foole now, ſpeake your minde Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Art thou not breeding Teeth?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: How? Teeth?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Yes Teeth, thou would'ſt not be ſo froward elſe.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Teeth?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Come, 'twill make thee
A little reumatique, but that's all one,
Weel'e have a Bib, for ſpoyling of thy doublet;
And a fring'd Muckender, hang at thy girdle,
I'le be thy Nurſe, and get a Corall for thee:
And a fine Ring of Bells.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Faith this is ſomewhat
Too much Fabritio, to your friend that loves you;
Me thinkes your goodneſſe, rather ſhould invent,
A way to make my follies leſſe, then breed 'em;
I ſhould have been more moderate to you,
But I ſee ye deſpiſe me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Now I love yee,
There, take your Sword, continue ſo: I dare not
Stay now to try your patience, Soone I'le meet yee,
And as you love your honours, and your ſtate,
Redeeme your ſelfe well to the Gentlewoman,
Farewell 'till ſoone. Exit Fab.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Well I ſhall thinke of this. Exit Jac.

div.head: Scaena Sexta.
div.stage: Enter Hoſt, Piſo, and Boy with a glaſſe of wine.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Nothing 'ith world but a dri'd Tongue or two—

sp.speaker: Hoſt
sp.l: Taſt him and tell me.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Is a valiant wine,
This muſt be he mine Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: This ſhall be Ipſe,
Oh he 's a develiſh bitten wine, a Tyrant;
Where he layes hold Sir, This is he that ſcornes
Small Beere ſhould quench him, or a fooliſh Caudell
Bring him to bed; no if he flinch I'le ſhame him,
And draw him out to mull amongſt old Midwives.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: There is a Souldier, I would have thee better
Above the reſt, becauſe he thinkes there's no man
Can give him drinke enough.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: What kinde of man?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.l: That thou mayſt know him perfectly, hee's one
Of a left-handed making, a lanck thing,
As if his belly were tane up with ſtraw,
To hunt a match.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Has he no beard to ſhew him?

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Faith but a little; yet enough to note him,
Which growes in parcells here, and there a remnant:
And that thou maiſt not miſſe him, he is one
That weares his fore-head in a vellet ſcabberd.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: That note's enough, he's mine, I'le fuddle him
Or lye 'ith ſudds; you will be here too?

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Yes, till ſoone, farewell and beare up.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: If I do not,
Say I am recreant; I'le get things ready.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: 'TIs ſtrange thou ſhould'ſt be thus, with thy diſcretion

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I am ſure I am ſo.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am well you ſee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Keep your ſelfe warme then, & go home, & ſleepe,
And pray to God thou maiſt continue ſo;
Would I had gon to'th Devill of an arrant,
When I was made a foole to ſee her: Leave me
I am not fit for converſation.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Why, thou art worſe then I was.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Therefore leave me,
The nature of my ſickneſſe is not eas'd
By company, or councell, I am mad,
And if you follow me with queſtions
Shall ſhew my ſelfe ſo.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: This is more then errour.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pray be content, that you have made me thus,
And do not wonder at me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Let me know, but what you meane to do and I am gon
I would be lo'ath to leave you thus elſe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nothing
That needs your feare, that is ſufficient;
Farewell, and pray for me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I would not leave you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You muſt and ſhall.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I will then: would yon woman
Had been ten fathom under ground, when firſt
I ſaw her eyes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yet ſhe had been dangerous,
For to ſome wealthy Rocke of pretious ſtone,
Or mine of gold as tempting, her faire body
Might have been turn'd; which once found out by labour
And brought to uſe, having her ſpells within it,
Might have corrupted States, and ruin'd Kingdomes
Which had been fearefull (Friend) Go, when I ſee thee
Next, I will be as thou art, or no more.
Pray do not follow me, you'l make me angry.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Heav'n grant you may be right againe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Amen. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Score a gallon of Sack, and a pinte of Olives to the Vnicorne.

sp.speaker: Above within.
sp.l: Why drawer?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A non, a non.

sp.speaker: Another boy.
sp.l: Looke into the Nags head there.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.l: Score a quart of Claret to the Bar,
And a pound of Sauſages into the flower-pott.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: The Divell's in their throates, anon, anon.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Mull a pinte of Sack there for the women in the Flower-deluce, & put in ginger enough, they belch like potguns,
sp.l: And Robbin fetch Tobacco for the Peacock, they will not
Drunke till midnight elſe: how now how does my Maſter.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.l: Faith he lyes drawing on a pace.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: That's an ill ſigne.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.l: And fumbles with the pots too.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Then ther's no way but one with him.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.l: All the reſt.
Except the Captaine are in Limbo patrum,
Where they lye ſod in ſack.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Does he beare up ſtill.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.l: Afore the winde ſtill, with his lightes up bravely
All he takes in I think he turnes to Iuleps,
Or has a world of Stoage in his belly,
The reſt looke all like fire-drakes, and lye ſcatter'd
Like ruſhes round about the roome. My Maſter
Is now the louing'ſt man, I thinke above ground,

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Would he were always drunke then.
Within. Drawer.

sp.speaker: 2. B.
sp.l: Anon, anon Sir,

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: And ſwears I ſhall be free to morrovv, and ſo vveeps
And calls upon my Miſtris.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Then he's right.

sp.speaker: 1. B.
sp.l: And ſvvears the Captain muſt lye this night with her
And bad me breake it to her vvith diſcretion,
That he may leave an iſſue after him:
Able to entertaine a dutch Ambaſſador,
And tells him feelingly how ſweete ſhe is,
And hovv he ſtoole her from her friendes i'th Countrey;
And brought her up diſguiz'd vvith the Carriers,
And vvas nine nights bereaving her her maiden head,
And the tenth got a dravver, here they come.
Within cry drawer. Anon, anon, ſpeake to the Tyger, Peter.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Ther's my Bells boyes, my ſilver Bell.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Would he vvere hang'd
As high as I could ring him.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Captaine.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Hoe Boy.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Robin, ſufficient ſingle Beere, as cold as chriſtall,
Quench Robin, quench.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: I am gon Sir.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Shall vve beare up ſtill? Captaine hovv I love thee?
Sweete Captaine let me kiſſe thee, by this hand
I love thee next to Malmeſey in a morning,
Of things tranſitory.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I love thee too, as far as I can love a fatt man.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Do'ſt thou Captaine?
Sweetly? and hartily?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: With all my heart Boy.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Then welcome death, come cloſe mine eyes ſweet Captaine
Thou ſhalt have all.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What ſhall your wife have then?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Why ſhe ſhall have beſides my bleſſing, and a ſilver ſpoone
Enough to keepe her ſtirring in the world,
Three little Children, one of them was mine
Upon my conſcience, th'other two are Pagans.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: 'Twere good ſhe had a little fooliſh money,
To rub the time a way with.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Not a rag,
Not a Deniere, no let her ſpin a Gods name:
And raiſe her houſe againe,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not dye though,
Boy ſee your Maſter ſafe delivered,
He's ready to lye in.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: God night.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: God morrow,
Drinke tell the Cow come home, 'tis all pay'd boyes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A pox of Sack.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Marry God bleſſe my Buts, Sack is a jewell,
'Tis comfortable Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: More Beere boy.
Uery ſufficient ſingle Beere.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here Sir.
How is it Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: But ev'n ſo, ſo.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Go before finely Robin, and prepare
My wife, bid her be right and ſtreight, I come boy
And Sirha, if they quarrell let 'em uſe,
Their owne diſcretions, by all meanes, and ſtir not,
And he that's kill'd ſhall be as ſweetly buried;
Captaine, adieu, adieu ſweet bully Captai ne,
One kiſſe before I dye, one kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Farewell Boy.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: All my ſweet boyes farewell. Exit Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Go ſleep, you are drunke.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, I'le ſee you at your Lodging,
You looke not luſtily, a quart more.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No Boy.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Get us a Torch.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: 'Tis day Sir.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: That's all one.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Are not thoſe the ſtars, thou ſcurvy Boy?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is not Charle-waine there, tell me that, there?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Yes;
I have paid 'em truely: do not vex him Sirha.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Confeſſe it Boy, or as I live I'le beate
Midnight into thy braines.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I do confeſſe it.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Then live, and draw more ſmall Beere preſently.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Come Boyes, let's hug together, and be loving,
And ſing, and do brave things cheerely my hearts,
A pox a being ſad; now, could I fly
And turne the world about upon my finger,
Come ye ſhall love me, I am an honeſt fellow:
Hang care and fortune, we are friendes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No Captaine.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Do not you love me? I love you too dearely.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: No by no meanes; you are a fighting Captaine,
And kill up ſuch poore people as we are, by'th dozens.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: As they kill flyes with Fox-tailes, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Me thinkes now as I ſtand, the Captaine ſhewes,
To be a very mercifull young man.
(And pre'thee Piſo, let me have thy opinion)

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Then he ſhall have mercy, that mercifull is,
Or all the Painters are Apocrypha.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: I am glad you have your witts yet, will ye go?

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: You had beſt ſay we are drunke.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Ye are.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yee lye.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Y'are Rascalls, drunken rascalls.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: 'Tis ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: And now I'le tell you why, before I beate yee,
You have been tampring any time theſe three dayes,
Thus to diſgrace me.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: That's a lye too.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Well Sir,
Yet I thanke God I have turn'd your points on you,
For which I'le ſpare yee ſomewhat, halfe a beating.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: I'le make you fart fire Captaine, by this hand,
And ye provoke, do not provoke I'de wiſh you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: How do you like this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sure I am inchanted.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Stay till I draw.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Deſpatch then, I am angry.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: And thou ſhalt ſee how ſodainly I'e kil thee.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Thou darſt not draw, ye cold, tame, mangy Cowards
Ye drunken Rogues, can nothing make you valiant?
Not wine, nor beating?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: If this way be ſufferd
'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Go ther's your way, go and ſleep:
I have pitty on you, you ſhall have the reſt
To morrow when wee meete.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Come Lodowick,
Hee's monſtrous drunke now, ther's no talking with him.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: I am ſo, when I am ſober, I'le do more. Exit Lod. & Piſo.
Boy wher's mine Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hee's on his bed a ſleepe Sir. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Let him alone then: Now am I high proofe
For my action, now could I fight bravely,
And charge into a wilde fire; or I could love
Any man living now, or any woman,
Or indeed any creature that loves Sack
Extreamly, monſtrouſly; I am ſo loving,
Iuſt at this inſtant, that I might be brought
I feele it, with a little labour, now to talke
With a juſtice of peace, that to my nature
I hate next an ill Sword: I will do
Some ſtrange brave thing now, and I have it here:
Pray God the ayre keepe out; I feele it buzing. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Shee loves him too much, that's the plaine truth Fredrick
For which if I might be beleev'd, I thinke her
A ſtrange forgetter of her ſelfe; ther's Iulio,
Or twenty more—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: In your eye I believe you,
But credit me the Captaine is a man:
Lay but his rough affections by, as worthy.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: So is a reſty Iade, a horſe of ſervice,
If he would leave his nature, give me one
By your leave Sir to make a husband of
Not to be wean'd, when I ſhould marry him;
Me thinkes a man is miſery enough,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You are too bitter,
I would not have him worſe.
Yet I ſhall ſee you hamper'd one day Lady,
I do not doubt it, for this hereſie

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: I'le burne before; come pre'thee leave this ſadneſſe;
This walking by thy ſelfe to ſee the Divell,
This mumps, this Lachrimae, this love in ſippets;
It fitts thee like a French-hood.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Does it ſo?
I am ſure it fits thee to be ever talking,
And nothing to the purpoſe, take up quickly;
Thy witt will founder of all foure elſe wench,
I thou hold'ſt this pace; take up when I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Before your Brother fly?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I can endure it.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Heer's Raw-head come againe; Lord how he lookes?
Pray God we ſcape with broken pates.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Were I hee,
Thou ſhould'ſt not want thy wiſh, he has been drinking
Has he not Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes but do not finde it.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Peace and let's heare his wiſedome.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You will mad him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I am ſomewhat bold, but that's all one.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: A ſhort and pithy ſaying of a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: As I live
Thou art a ſtrange mad wench.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: To make a parſon.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Ladyes I meane to kiſſe yee

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: How he wipes his mouth like a young Preacher;
We ſhall have it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: In order as you ly before me; firſt
I'le begin with you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: With me Sir?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Yes
If you will promiſe me to kiſſe in eaſe.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I care not if I venture.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I will kiſſ according to mine owne inventions
As I ſhall ſee cauſe; ſweetly I would wiſh you,
I love ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Yes indeed do I,
Would I could tell you how.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I would you would Sir.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I would to God I could, but 'tis ſufficient,
I love you with my heart.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Alas poore heart.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And I am ſorry; but wee'l talk of that,
Hereafter if it pleaſe God.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ev'n when you will Sir.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Hee's diſmall drunk, would he were muſled.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You
I take it are the next.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Go to him foole.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Not I, 'a will bite me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: When witt? when?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Good Captaine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Nay, and you play boa-peepe; I'le ha, no mercy
But catch as catch may.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Nay, I'le not defend ye.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Good Captaine do not hurt me, I am ſorry
That ere I anger'd ye.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: I'le tew you for't
By this hand witt, unleſſe you kiſſe diſcreetly.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: No more Sir.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Yes a little more ſweet witt,
One taſt more o' your office: go thy wayes
With thy ſmall kettle Drumes; upon my conſcienc
Thou art the beſt, that e're man laid his leg o'er.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: He ſmells juſt like a Cellar,
Fye upon him.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Sweete Lady now to you.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: For loves ſake kiſſe him.

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.l: I ſhall not keep my countenance.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Trye pre'thee.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Pray be not coy ſweet woman, for I'le kiſſe ye,
I am blunt
But you muſt pardon me.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: O God my ſides.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Why ha, ha, ha? why laugh?
Why all this noyſe ſweet Ladyes?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Luſty Laurence,
See what a Gentlewoman you have ſaluted;
Pray God ſhe prove not quick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Where were thine eyes
To take me for a woman, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Who art 'a, art 'a mortall?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am Fredrick

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Then Fredrick is an Aſſe,
A ſcurvy Fredrick to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sweet Captaine.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: A way woman;
Go ſtich and ſerve God, I deſpiſe thee woman,
And Fredrick ſhall be beaten; S'blood ye Rogue
Have you none elſe to make your puppies of, but me?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I pre'thee be more patient
Ther's no hurt done.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: S'blood but there ſhall be, Scab.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Help, help for loves ſake.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Whoſe within there?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: So now you have made a faire hand.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have kill'd me— Fal as kill'd.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Call in ſome Officers, and ſtay the Captaine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You ſhall not need.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: This is your drunkenneſſe.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O me unhappy Brother, Fredrick,
Looke but upon me, do not part ſo from me,
Set him a little higher he is dead.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: O villaine, villaine. Enter Fabritio.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: How now what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O Sir my Brother! o my deareſt Brother!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: This drunken trowgh has kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Kill'd him?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Yes.
For heaven God ſake hang him quickly, he will do
Ev'ry day ſuch a murder elſe. there is nothing
But a ſtrong Gallowes that can make him quiet,
I finde it in his nature too late.

sp.speaker: Fabr.
sp.l: Pray be quiet,
Let me come to him.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Some go for a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Oh what a wretched woman has he made me!
Let me alone good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: To what a fortune,
Haſt thou reſerv'd thy life.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Never entreat me, for I will not know thee,
Nor utter one word for thee, unleſſe it be
To have thee hang'd; for God ſake bee more temperate.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I have a ſword ſtill, and I am a villaine.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: &c. Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Away with him for heavens ſake
He's too deſperate for our enduring.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Come, you ſhall ſleepe, come ſtrive not
Ile have it ſo, here take him to his lodging, and
See him laid before you part.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: We will Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ne're wonder, I am living yet, and well,
I thanke you ſiſter for your griefe, pray keepe it
Till I am fitter for it.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Do you live Sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes, but 'twas time to counterfeit, he was grown
To ſuch a madneſſe in his wine.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Twas well Sir,
You had that good reſpect unto his temper,
That no worſe followd.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If I had ſtood him, certaine one of us muſt have periſh'd,
How now Franke?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Beſhrew my heart I tremble like an aſpine.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Let him come here no more for heavens ſake
Unleſſe he be in chaines.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I would faine ſee him
After he has ſlept, Fabritio, but to try
How he wil be; chide him, and bring him backe.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: You'l never leave till you be worried with him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Come brother, wee'l walke in, and laugh a little.
To get this Fever off me.

sp.speaker: Clo
sp.l: Hang him ſquib,
Now could I grinde him into priming powder.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray will you leave your fooling?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Come, all friends. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Thou art enough to make an age of men ſo,
Thou art ſo croſſe and peeviſh.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I will chide him,
And if he be not graceleſſe, make him cry for't.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I would goe a mile (to ſee him cry) in ſlippers
He would looke ſo like a whay cheeſe;

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Would we might ſee him once more.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: If you dare
Venture a ſecond tryall of his temper
I make no doubt to bring him.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: No good Franke
Let him alone, I ſee his vaine lyes only
For falling out at Wakes and Beare-baitings,
That may expreſſe him ſturdy.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Now indeed
You are too ſharp ſweet ſiſter, for unleſſe
It be this ſin, which is enough to drown him,
I meane this ſowrneſſe, he's as brave a fellow,
As forward, and as underſtanding elſe
As any He that lives.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I doe beleeve you,
And good Sir when you ſee him, if we have
Diſtaſted his opinion any way,
Make peace againe.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I will: I'le leave ye Ladies.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Take heed you had beſt, h'as ſworn to pay you elſe.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I warrant you, I have been often threatned.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: When he comes next, I'le have the cough or tooth-ach,
Or ſomething that ſhall make me keepe my chamber,
I love him ſo well.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Would you would keepe your tongue. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I cannot keepe from this ungodly woman,
This Lelia, whom I know too, yet am caught,
Her looks are nothing like her; would her faults
Were all in Paris print upon her face,
Cum Privilegio, to uſe 'em ſtill.
I would write an Epiſtle before it, on the inſide of her maſque
And dedicate it to the whore of Babilon, with a preface upō
Her noſe to the gentle Reader; & they ſhould be to be ſold
At the ſigne of the Whores head i'th pottage pot, in what
Street you pleaſe: But all this helps not me;—I
Am made to be thus catch'd, paſt any redreſſe, with a thing
I contemn too.
I have read Epictetus twice over againſt the
Deſire of theſe outward things, and ſtill her face runs in
My mind, I went to ſay my prayers, and they were
So laid out o'th way, that if I could finde any prayers I
Had, I'me no Chriſtian.
This is the doore, and the ſhort
Is, I muſt ſee her againe.— He knockes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Tis I, I would ſpeake with your Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Did ſhe ſend for you?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No, what then? I would ſee her, prethee by thy leave.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Not by my leave; for ſhe will not ſee you, but doth hate you, and
Your friend, and doth wiſh you both hang'd, w^c^h being ſo proper
Men, is great pitty, that you are not.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: For your ſweet ſelf in particular, who ſhe reſolvs perſwaded your
Friend to neglect her, ſhe deemeth whip-cord the moſt
Convenient unction for your backe and ſhoulders.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Let me in, I'le ſatisfie her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And if it ſhal happen that you are in doubt of theſe my ſpeeches,
Inſomuch that you ſhal ſpend more time in arguing at the
Dore, I am fully perſwaded that my Miſtris in perſon from
Above, will utter her mind more at large by way of
Urine upon your head, that it may ſink the more ſoundly
Into your underſtanding faculties.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: This is the ſtrangeſt thing, good pretty ſoul, why doſt thou uſe me ſo?
I pray thee let me in ſweet heart.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Indeed I cannot ſweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Thou art a handſome one, and this croſſeneſs do's become thee.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Alas I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Eſpecially to me; thou knowſt when I was here, I ſaid I lik'd thee of
All thy Miſtriſs ſervants.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: So did I you, though it be not my fortune to expreſs
It at this preſent: for truly if you would cry, I cannot
Let you in.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pox on her, I muſt goe the down-right way: looke you
Here is ten pound for you, let me ſpeak with her.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I like your gold well, but it is a thing by heaven
I cannot doe, ſhee
Will not ſpeake with you, eſpecially at this time, ſhe has affaires.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: This makes her leave her jeſting yet, but take it
And let me ſee her, bring me to a place
Where undiſcern'd of herſelfe I may
Feede my deſiring eyes but halfe an houre.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why faith I think I can, and I wil ſtretch my wits
And body too for gold: if you will ſweare as you
Are gentle, not to ſtir, or ſpeake, where you ſhall
See or hear, now, or hereafter: give me your gold, I'le plant you

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why, as I am a Gentleman, I will not.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Enough, quicke, follow me.
Why where's this maid, ſhe ha's much care of her buſineſs. Nell?
I thinke ſhe be ſunke;—why Nell—whiew—

sp.speaker: Maid within.
sp.l: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I pray you heartily come away, oh, come, come, the Gentleman,
My Miſtris invited, is comming down the ſtreet, and the banquet
Not yet brought out?— They bring in the Banquet

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: within. Nell, Sirha?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I come forſooth.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Now muſt I walk: when ther's any fleſhly matters in hand, my
Miſtris ſends me of a four hours errand: but if I goe not
About mine own bodily buſineſſe as well as ſhee, I am a Turke. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What, all wide open? 'Tis the way to ſin
Doubtleſſe; but I muſt on; the gates of hell
Are not more paſſable then theſe; how they
Will be to get out, God knows, I muſt try.
'Tis very ſtrange, if there be any life
Within this houſe, would it would ſhew it ſelfe.
What's here? a Banquet? and no mouth to eate,
Or bid me do it? this is ſomething like
The entertainment of adventurous Knights
Entring enchanted Caſtles: For the manner
Though there be nothing diſmall to be ſeene
Amazes me a little; what is meant
By this ſtrange invitation? I will ſound
My Daughters meaning, e're I ſpeake to her,
If it be poſſible, for by my voyce— Muſique.
She will diſcover me! hark, whence is this.
COme hither you that love, and heare me ſing
of joyes ſtill growing
Green, freſh, and luſty, as the pride of Spring,
and ever blowing.
Come hither youths that bluſh, and dare not know
what is deſire,
And olde men worſe then you, that cannot blow
one ſparke of fire.
And with the power of my enchanting Song,
Boyes ſhall be able men, and old men young.
Come hither you that hope, and you that cry,
leave off complaining,
Youth, ſtrength, and beauty, that ſhall never dye,
are here remaining.
Come hither fooles, and bluſh, you ſtay ſo long
from being bleſt,
And mad men worſe then you, that ſuffer wrong,
Yet ſeeke no reſt.
And in an houre, with my enchanting Song,
You ſhall be ever pleas'd, and yovng maids long.

div.stage: Enter Lelia and her maid with a Night-gowne and Slippers.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Sir you are welcome hither, as this kiſſe
Given with a larger freedome then the uſe
Of ſtrangers will admit, ſhall witneſſe to you.
Put the gowne on him, in this chaire ſit downe;
Give him his ſlippers: be not ſo amaz'd,
Here's to your health, and you ſhall feele this wine
Stir lively in me, in the dead of night.
Give him ſome wine; fall to your banquet Sir,
And let us grow in mirth; though I am ſet
Now thus far off you, yet four glaſſes hence
I will ſit here,
And try, till both our bloods
Shoote up and downe to finde a paſſage out,
Then mouth, to mouth will we walke up to bed,
And undreſſe one another as we goe;
Where both my treaſure, body, and my ſoule
Are your's to be diſpos'd of.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Umh, umh.— Makes ſignes of his white head & heard.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: You are old,
Is that your meaning? why, you are to me
The greater novelty, all our freſh youth
Are daily offer'd me, though you performe
As you thinke little, yet you ſatisfie
My appetite: from your experience
I may learn ſomething in the way of luſt
I may be better for. But I can teach
Theſe young ones;
But this day I did refuſe
A paire of 'em, Julio, and Angilo,
And told them they were as they were
Raw fooles and whelps.Ang. makes diſcontented ſignes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Pray God he ſpeak notMaid lais her finger croſſe her mouth to him.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Why ſpeak you not ſweet Sir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Umh.— Stops his ears, ſhews he is troubled with the Muſick.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Peace there, that muſique, now Sir ſpeak
To me.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Umh.— Points at the Maid.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Why? would you have her gone? you need not keep
Your freedome in for her; ſhe knows my life
That ſhe might write it;
Thinke ſhe is a ſtone?
Shee is a kinde of bawdy Confeſſor,
And will not utter ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Umh.— Points at her againe.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Be gone then, ſince he needs will have it ſo,
Tis all one. Exit Maid. — Fath. locks the doore.
'Is all now as you would? come meet me then,
And bring a thouſand kiſſes on thy lips,
And I will rob thee of 'em, and yet leave
Thy lips as wealthy as they were before.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yes, all is as I would but thou.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: By heaven 'tis my Father.— Starts

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: And I do beſeech thee
Leave theſe unheard of luſts which worſe become thee,
Then mocking of thy Father; let thine eyes
Reflect upon thy ſoule, and there behold
How loathed blacke it is; and whereas now
Thy face is heavenly faire, but thy minde foule,
Goe but into thy Cloſet, and there cry
Till thou haſt ſpoil'd that face, and thou ſhalt finde
How excellent a change, thou wilt have made
For inward beauty.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Though I know him now
To be my Father, never let me live
If my luſt do abate.
I'le take upon me
To have known him all this while.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Looke, doſt thou know me?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I knew yee Sir before.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: What didſt thou do?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Knew you, and ſo unmov'dly have you borne
All the ſad croſſes that I laid upon you,
With ſuch a noble temper, which indeed
I purpoſely caſt on you, to diſcern
Your carriage in calamity, and you
Have undergone 'em with that brave contempt,
That I have turn'd the reverence of a childe
Into the hot affection of a Lover.
Nor can there on the earth be found but yours
A ſpirit fit to meete with mine.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: A woman? thou art not ſure.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Looke and beleeve.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Thou art
Something created to ſucceed the Devill
When be growes weary of his envious courſe,
And compaſſing the world; but I beleeve thee
Thou didſt but meane to try my patience,
And do'ſt ſo ſtill; but better be advis'd:
And make thy tryall with ſome other things
That ſafelier will admit a dalliance:
And if it ſhould be earneſt, underſtand
How curſt thou art, ſo far from heaven, that thou
Beleev'ſt it not enough to damn alone,
Or with a ſtranger, but wouldſt heape all ſins
Unnaturall upon this aged head
And draw thy Father to thy Bed, and hell.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd Sir, 'tis not againſt nature
For us to lye together; if you have
An arrow of the ſame tree with your bow,
Is't more unnaturall to ſhoot it there
Then in another? 'Tis our generall nature
To procreate, as fires is to conſume,
And it will trouble you to finde a ſticke
The fire will turne from: If't be natures will
We ſhould not mixe, ſhe will diſcover to us
Some moſt apparant croſſeneſſe, as our organs
Will not be fit; which if we do perceive
Wee'l leave, and thinke it is her pleaſure
That we ſhould deale with others.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: The dores are faſt; thou ſhalt not ſay a prayer,
'Tis not Gods will thou ſhouldſt; when this is done
I'le kill my ſelfe, that never man may tell me
I got theeFath. draws his ſword. Angilo diſcovers himſelf..

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I pray you Sir, help ther, for Gods ſake Sir.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hold reverend Sir, for honour of your age.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Whoe's that?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: For ſafety of your ſoule, and of the ſoule
Of that too wicked woman yet to dye.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What art thou? and how cam'ſt thou to that place?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I am a man ſo ſtrangely hither come,
That I have broke an oath in ſpeaking this,
But I believe 'twas better broke then kept,
And I deſire your patience; let me in,
And I proteſt I will not hinder you
In any act you wiſh, more then by word,
If ſo I can perſwade you, that I will not
Uſe violence, I'le throw my ſword down to you:
This houſe holds none but I, only a maid
Whom I will locke faſt in as I come downe.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I do not know thee, but thy tongue doth ſeeeme
To be acquainted with the truth ſo well
That I will let thee in: throw down thy ſword.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: There 'tis.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: How came he there? I am betraid to ſhame,
The feare of ſodaine death ſtrook me all over
So violently, that I ſcarce have breath He lets in Ang. and lockes the doore.
To ſpeake yet: But I have it in my head,
And out it ſhall, that (Father) may perhaps
O're-reach you yet.

sp.speaker: Fat.
sp.l: Come Sir, what is't you ſay?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: My Angilo, by all the joyes of love
Thou art as welcome as theſe plyant arms
Twin'd round, and faſt about thee, can perſwade thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I was in ſuch a fright before thou cam'ſt,
You old mad fellow, (it will make thee laugh
Though it feared me) has talkt ſo wildly here—
Sirrha, he ruſht in at my dores, and ſwore
He was my Father, and I thinke beleev'd it:
But that he had a ſword, and threatned me—
I'faith he was good ſport, good, thruſt him out
That thou and I may kiſſe together; wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Are you her Champion? & with theſe fair words,
Got in to reſcue her from me. Offer to run at him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hold ſir,
I ſweare I doe not harbour ſuch a thought,
I ſpeake it not, for that you have two ſwords,
But for tis truth.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Two ſwords my Angilo?
Thinke this, that thou haſt two young brawny armes
And ne're a ſword, and he has two good ſwords
And ne're an arme to uſe 'em; ruſh upon him,
I could have beaten him with this weake body,
If I had had the ſpirit of a man.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Stand from me, and leave talking, or by heaven
I'le trample thy laſt damning word out of thee.

sp.speaker: Fa●.
sp.l: Why do you hinder me then? ſtand away
And I will rid her quickly.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Would I were
Cleare of this buſineſſe, yet I cannot pray.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh be advis'd, why you were better kill her
If ſhe were good; Convey her from this place
Where none but you, and ſuch as you appoint
May viſite her; where let her heare of nought
But death and damning, which ſhe hath deſerv'd,
Till ſhe be truly, juſtly ſorrowful,
And then lay mercy to her, who does know
But ſhe may mend?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: But whither ſhould I beare her?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: To my houſe,
'Tis large, and private, I will lend it you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir, and happily it fits
With ſome deſigne I have, but how ſhall we
Convey her?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Will they cary me away?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: For ſhe wil ſcratch and kick, & ſcream ſo loud
That people will be drawn to reſcue her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why? none can hear her here, but her own maid,
Who is as faſt as ſhe.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: But in the ſtreete?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why, we will take 'em both into the Kitchin,
There binde 'em, and then gag 'em, and then throw 'em
Into a Coach I'le bring to the backe-dore,
And hurry 'em away.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſo,
I owe you much for this; and I may pay you,
There is your ſword, lay hold upon her quickly,
This way with me, thou diſobedient childe.
Why do's thy ſtubborn heart beat at thy breaſt?
Let it be ſtill, for I will have it ſearch'd
Till I have found a well of living teares
Within it, that ſhall ſpring out of thine eyes,
And flow all o're thy body foul'd with ſin,
Till it have waſh'd it quite without a ſtain. They drag her.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Help! help! ah! ah!
Murther, I ſhall be murthered, I ſhall be murthered.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: This helps thee not.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Baſely murdered, baſely.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I warrant you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: THis roguy Captaine has made fine work with us.

sp.speaker: Pi●o
sp.l: I would the Devill in a ſtorm would carry him
Home to his Gariſon againe; I ake all over,
That I am ſure of; Certainly my body
Is of a wild-fire, for my head rings backward,
Or elſe I have a moriſe in my braines.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'le deale no more with ſouldiers: wel remembred,
Did not the Viſion promiſe to appeare
About this time again?

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Yes, here he comes:
He's juſt on's word.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: O, they be here together,
Shee's penitent, and by my troth I ſtagger
Whether (as now ſhe is) either of theſe
Two fooles be worthy of her; yet becauſe
Her youth is prone to fall againe, ungovern'd,
And marriage now may ſtay her, one of 'em:
And Piſo, ſince I underſtand him abler,
Shall be the man; the other beare the charges,
And willingly, as I will handle it.
I have a Ring here, which he ſhall believe
Is ſent him from a woman I have thought of:
But e're I leave it, I'le have one of his
In pawne worth two on't: for I will not looſe
By ſuch a meſſe of ſugar-ſops as this is:
I am too old.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: It moves againe, let's meet it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Now if I be not out, we ſhall have fine ſport,
I am glad I have met you Sir, ſo happily,
You do remember me, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I doe Sir.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: This is a ſhort praeludium to a challenge.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I have a meſſage Sir, that much concerns you,
And for your ſpeciall good; Nay you may heare too.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: VVhat ſhould this fellow meane?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: There is a Lady,
(How the poore thing begins to warme already)
Come to this Towne, (as yet a ſtranger here Sir)
Faire, young, and rich, both in poſſeſſions,
And all the graces that make up a woman,
A widow, and a vertuous one: It workes,
He needs no broath upon't,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVhat of her Sir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: No more but this; ſhe loves you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Loves me?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yes.
And with a ſtrong affection, but a faire one,
If ye be wiſe and thankfull, you are made: ther's the whole matter.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I am ſure I heare this.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Here is a Ring Sir, of no little value:
Which after ſhe had ſeen you at a window,
She bad me haſt, and give it, when ſhe bluſh'd
Like a blown roſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But pray Sir by your leave—
Me thinks your yeares ſhould promiſe no ill meaning.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I am no Bawd, nor cheater, nor a coarſer
Of broken-winded women: if you feare me
I'le take my leave: and let my Lady uſe
A fellow of more forme; an honeſter
I am ſure ſhe cannot.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Stay, you have confirm'd me,
Yet let me feele, you are in health.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I hope ſo,
My water's well enough, and my pulſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Then
All may be excellent: pray pardon me;
For I am like a boy that had found money,
Afraid I dreame ſtill.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Sir, what kind of woman?
Of what proportion is your Lady?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I'le tell you preſently her very picture,
Do you know a woman in this towne they call,
Stay, yes, it is ſo, Lelia?

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Not by ſight.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Nor you Sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Theſe are precious Rogues
To raile upon a woman they never ſaw;
So they would uſe their Kindred.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: We have heard though
She is very faire and goodly.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Such another,
Juſt of the ſame complexion, making, ſpeech,
But a thought ſweeter is my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Then
Shee muſt be excellent indeed.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Indeed ſhe is,
And you will finde it ſo; you do beleeve me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes marry do I, and I am ſo alter'd —

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Your happineſſe will alter any man.
Do not delay the time Sir: at a houſe
Where Don Valaſco lay, the Spaniſh Signior
(Which now is Signieur Angelos) ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: But before you ſhew your ſelfe,
Let it be night by all meanes, willingly
By day ſhe would not have ſuch gallants ſeene
Repair unto her 'tis her modeſty.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'le goe and fit my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Doe, and be ſure
You ſend proviſion in, in full abundance,
Fit for the marriage; for this night I know
Shee will be yours: Sir, have you never a token
Of worth to ſend her backe againe? you muſt,
Shee will expect it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes, pray give her this,
And with it all I have; I am made for ever. Exit Lod.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Well, thou haſt fooles lucke; ſhould I live as long
As an old oake, and ſay my prayers hourly
I ſhould not be the better of a penny.
I think the Devill be my ghoſtly Father;
Upon my conſcience I am full as handſome,
I am ſure I have more wit, and more performance,
Which is a pretty matter.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Do you thinke ſir,
That your friend Signeur Piſo will be conſtant
Unto my Lady? you ſhould know him well.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Who? Signieur Piſo?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yes, the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: VVhy, you are wide Sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Is not his name Piſo?

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: No, mine is Piſo.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: 'Tis indeed Sir,
And his is Lodowicke.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Then I am undone Sir,
For I was ſent at firſt to Piſo; what a raſcall
VVas I, ſo ignorantly to miſtake you?

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Peace.
There is no harme done yet.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Now 'tis too late,
I know my errour:
At turning of a Street,
For you were then upon the right hand of him,
You chang'd your places ſudainly: where I
(Like a croſſe Block-head) loſt my memory:
What ſhall I do? my Lady utterly
Will put me from her favour.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Never feare it,
I'le be thy guard, I warrant thee, O, O,
Am I at length reputed? for the Ring,
I'le fetch it back with a light vengance from him:
Had better keep tame Devills, then that Ring;
Art thou not Steward?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt be ſhortly

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Lord how he takes it?

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: I'le go ſhift me ſtreight;
Art ſure it was to Piſo?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: O too ſure Sir.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: I'le mount thee if I live for't,
Give me patience heav'n to be are this bleſſing I beſeech thee;
I am but man; I pre'thee breake my head
To make me underſtand, I am ſenſible.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Lend me your dagger, and I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: No
I believe now like a good Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Good Sir make haſt; I dare not go without ye
Since I have ſo miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: 'Tis no matter,
Meet me within this halfe houre at St. Margrets.
Well go thy wayes old leg, thou haſt the trick on't. Exit. Piſo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How now? the newes?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Well, paſſing well, I have 'em,
Both in a leaſh and made right for my purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am glad on't I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Whether man?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If all go right, I may be faſt enough too.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I cry you mercie Sir, I know your meaning,
Clora's the woman, ſhe's Francks bedfellow,
Commend me to 'em, and go Julio
Bring 'm to ſupper all, to grace this matter;
They ſerve for witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.p: I will, Farewell. Exit Jul at one dore, & Ang, & Fa, at another.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Clora, Franck, and Fredrick, and Maid.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Siſter, I brought you Jacamo to the doore,
He has forgot all that he ſaid laſt night:
And ſhame of that makes him more loath to come,
I left Fabritio perſwading him, but 'tis in vaine.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Alas my fortune Clora.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Now Franck, See what a kind of man you love,
That loves you when hee's drunk; If ſo
Faith I would marry him; My friends I hope
Would make him drink.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: 'Tis well conſider'd Franck, he has ſuch pretty humours then,
Beſides being a Souldier, 'tis better he ſhould love
You when hee's drunck, then when hee's ſober, for then he
Will be ſure to love you, the greateſt part on's life.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And were not I a happy woman then?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: That ever was borne Franck. y'faith—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How now? what ſayes hee?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Faith you may as well tice a dog up with a whip, and bell
As him, by telling him of love and women, he ſweares
They mock him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Looke how my Siſter weepes.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: VVhy who can helpe it?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes, you may ſafly ſweare ſhe loves him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: VVhy ſo I did; and may do all the oathes,
Arithmatique can make, ere he believe me,
And ſince he was laſt drunk, he is more jealous
They would abuſe him: If we could perſwade him
She lov'd, he would embrace it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She her ſelfe
Shall bate ſo much of her owne modeſty
To ſweare it to him; with ſuch teares as now
You ſee raine from her.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I believe 'twould worke,
But would you have her do't i'th open ſtreet?
Or if you would hee'le run away from her,
How ſhall we get him hither?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: By entreaty.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt impoſſible, No, If we could
Anger him hither, as ther is no way
But that to bring him; and then hold him faſt
Women, and men, whilſt ſhe delivers to him the truth
Seal'd with her teares, he would be plaine
As a pleas'd child; he walkes below for me
Under the window.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: VVee'le anger him I warrant ye,
Let one of the maides take a good bowle of water,
Or ſay it be a piſſ-pott, and power't on's head.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Content hang me If I like not the caſt of it rarely, for no queſtion it,
Is an approv'd receipt to fetch ſuch a fellow
Take all the women-kind in this houſe, betwixt the age of one,
And one hundred, & let them take unto them a pott or a
Bowle containing ſeven quarts or upwards, & let them
Never leave, till the above named,
Pott or Bowle become full, then let one of them ſtretch out
Her arme and power it on his head, add Probatum eſt, it
VVill fetch him, for in his anger he will run up, & then let
Us alone.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Go you and do it. Exit Maid.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good Clora, no.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Away I ſay & do it; never feare, we have enough of that
Water ready diſtill'd.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why this will make him mad Fabritio,
Hee'le neither love me drunke, nor ſober now.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I warrant you: what, is the wench come up?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Art thou there wench?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Looke out then if thou canſt ſee him.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Yes I ſee him, & by my troth he ſtands ſo faire I could not
Hold were he my Father; his hat's of too, & he's ſcratching
His head.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: O waſh that hand I pre'thee. (I have throwne thee

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: God ſend thee good luck, this the ſecond time,
Out to day, ha, ha, ha, juſt on's head.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: What does he now?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: He gathers ſtones, God's light, he breakes all the Street windows

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Whore's Bawdes, your windowes, your windowes.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Now he is breaking all the low windowes with his Sword,
Excellent ſport, Now he's beating a fellow that laugh'd at him;
Truely the man takes it patiently; Now he goes downe the Street
Gravely, looking on each ſide, ther's not one more dare laugh.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Does he go on?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Fabritio, you have undone a Maid Fran. kneeles.
By treachery; know you ſome other better,
You would prefer your friend to? If you do not
Bring him againe, I have no other hope,
But you that made me looſe hope, If you faile me,
I ne're ſhall ſee him, but ſhall languiſh out
A diſcontented life, and dye contemn'd.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: This vexes me, I pray you be more patient lift her up
If I have any truth, let what will happen,
I'le bring him preſently, Do you all ſtand
At the Street dore, the Maides, and all, to watth
When I come backe, and have ſome private place
To ſhuffle me into, for he ſhall follow
In fury, but I know I can out run him:
As he comes in, clap all faſt hold on him,
And uſe your owne diſcretions.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Wee will do it.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: But ſudainly for I will bring him hither,
With that unſtop'd ſpeed that you ſhall run over
All that's in's way: and though my life be ventur'd
'Tis no great matter, will do't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I thanke you,
Worthy Fabritio. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: I ever knew no woman could abide me,
But am I growne ſo contemptible, by being once drunke
Amongſt 'em, that they begin to throw piſſe on my head?
For ſurely it was piſſe huh, huh. ſeeme to ſmell.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Jacamo, how do'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Well, ſomething troubled with watriſh humours.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Foh, how thou ſtinck'ſt; pre'thee ſtand further of me
Me things theſe humours become thee better then thy dry
Chollerick humours, or thy wine-wet humours; ha?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You'r pleaſant, but Fabrito know I am not in the wood of
Suffering jeſt.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: If you be not i'th mood I hope you will not be moody
But truely I cannot blame the Gentlewoman, you ſtood eveſdropping,
Under their window, and would not come up.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Sir, I ſuſpect now, by your idle talke
Your hand was in't, which if I once believe,
Be ſure you ſhall account to me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: The Gentlewomen and the Maides have counted to you already
The next turne I ſee is mine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Let me dye but this is very ſtrange; good Fabritio
Do not provoake me ſo.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Provoke you? you'r growne the ſtrongeſt fellow; ther's no
Keeping company with you, phiſh; take you that.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O all the Devills? ſtand Slave. Fab. give him a box o'th ear ſodainly, & throws him frem him, & goes his walls, whilſt Iaca. drawes his Sword.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: follow me if thou dar'ſt.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Stay coward, ſtay.— Ja: runnes after Fabritio.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Fred. Fra. Clora. and Servant and Maid

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Be ready for I ſee Fabritio running,
And Jacamo behind him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Wher's the place.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That way Fabritio. Exit Fab.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Where art thou treacher? Fred. Clor, and Maid, lay hold on Jacamo.
What is the matter Sirs?
Why do you hold me? I am baſely wrong'd,
Torture, and hell, be with you; let me go. they drag him to a chaire and hold him downe in't.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Good Iacamo be patient, and but heare
What I can ſay, you know I am your friend,
If you yet doubt it, by my ſoule I am.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: S'death ſtand away;
I would my breath were poyſon.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: As I have life that which was throwne on you,
And this now done, were but to draw you hither
For cauſes weighty, that concerne your ſelfe
Uoid of all malice, which this Maid my Siſter
Shall tell you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Puh, a pox upon you all; you will not hold me
For ever here, and till you let me go,
I'le talke no more.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.l: As you'r a Gentleman
Let not this boldneſſe make me be beleev'd,
To be immodeſt; If there were a way
More ſilently to be acquainted with you
God knowes, that I would chooſe, But as it is
Take it in plaineſſe: I do love you more
Then you do your content, If you refuſe
To pitty me, I'le never ceaſe to weepe,
And when mine eyes be out I will be told
How faſt the teares I ſhed for you do fall,
And if they do not flow abundantly,
I'le fetch a ſigh ſhall make 'em ſtart, and leap,
As if the fire weare under.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Fine mocking, fine mocking.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Mocking? looke how ſhe weepes.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Do's ſhe counterfeit crying too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Behold how the teares flow, or pitty her
Or never more be call'd a man.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: How's this? ſoft you, ſoft you my Maſters: Is't poſſible thinke you,
She ſhould be in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Earneſt? I in earneſt: ſhe's a foole to breake ſo many ſleepes,
That would have been ſound ones, & venture ſuch a face, &
So much life, for ere an humorous aſſe i'th world.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why Clora? I have knowne you cry as much?
For Julio, that has not halfe his worth,
All night you write and weepe too much I feare
I do but what I ſhould.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: If I do write
I am anſwer'd Franck.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I would I might be ſo.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Good Fredrick let me go I would faine trye
If that thing do not counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Give me your Sword then.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No, but take my word,
As I am man, I will not hurt a creature
Under this roofe, before I have deliver'd
My ſelfe, as I am now into your handes,
Or have your full conſent.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is enough.

sp.speaker: Ja
sp.l: Gentlwoman, I pray you let me fele your face; I am an
Infidell, if ſhe do not weepe: Stay, wher's my handkerchife?
I'le wipe the old wett off, the freſh teares come, pox on't
I am a handſome, gratious fellow amongſt women, and
Knew't not Gentlewoman; how ſhould I know theſe
For me? Is not your Mother dead?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: By heaven they are for you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Slight I'le have my head corld, and powderd to teares are morrow
By breake of day; If you love me, I pray you kiſſe me,
For If I love you, it ſhall be ſuch love, as I will not be
A ſham'd of, If this be a mock— kiſſes,
It is the hartieſt, and the ſweeteſt mock
That ere I taſted, mock me ſo againe —kiſſe againe

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Fy Iacamo? why do you let her kneele
So long?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: It's true I had forgot it —lift her up,
And ſhould have done this twelve-moneth; pray you riſe
Fredrick, If I could all this while have been perſwaded ſhe could
Have lov'd me, doſt thou thinke I had not rather kiſſe her
Then another ſhould? and yet you may gull me for ought
I know, but if you do, hell take me If I do not cutt
All your throates ſleeping.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Oh do not thinke of ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Otherwiſe, If ſhe be in earneſt, the ſhort is I am.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Alas, I am.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: And I did not think it poſſible any woman
Could have lik'd this face, it's good for nothing, is't?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Yes it's worth forty ſhillings to pawne, being lind almoſt quite
Through with velvet.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis better then your Iulio's.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Thou thinkeſt ſo,
But otherwiſe, in faith it is not Franck —whilſt Iacamo is kiſſing Franck.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Hiſt Iacamo; How do'ſt thou Boy? ha?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Why very well, I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Do'ſt thou perceive the reaſon of matters, and paſſages,
Yet Sirah, or no?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: 'Tis wondrous good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I have done ſimply for you, but now you are beatten to ſome
Underſtanding, I pray you dally not with the Gentlewoman
But diſpatch your Matrimony, with all convenient ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He gives good counſell.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And I will follow it.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: And I you, prethee do not take it unkindly,
For truſt me I boxt thee for thy advancement,
A fooliſh deſire I had to joggle thee into preferment.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: I apprehend you Sir, & if I can ſtudy out a courſe
How a baſtinadoing may any waies raiſe your fortunes
In the State, you ſhall be ſure on't.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Oh Sir keepe your way, God ſend you much joy.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: And me my Iulio.
O God I heare his voyce, now he is true,
Have at a marriage Franck, as ſoone as you —Exeunt all but Fred.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Sir I would ſpeake with you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What is your haſty buſines friend?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: The Duke commandes your preſent attendance at Court.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The cauſe?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: I know not in particular; but this
Many are ſent for more, about affaires
Forraigne I take it Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will be there
Within this houre, returne my humble ſervice.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: I will Sir. Exit Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Farewell friend, what new's with you?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Miſtris would deſire you Sir to follow
With all the haſt you can, ſhe is gon to Church,
To marry Captaine Iacamo, and Iulio,
To do as much for the young merry Gentlewoman,
Faire Miſtris Clora.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Julio, marry Clora?
Thou art deceiv'd I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No ſure Sir,
I ſaw their lips as cloſe upon the bargaine
As Cockles.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Give 'em joy, I cannot now goe,
The Duke hath ſent for me in haſt.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: This note Sir: when you are free, will bring you where they are. Ex.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: reades. You ſhall finde us all at Signeur Angilo's,
Where Piſo, and the worthy Lelia
Of famous memory are to be married,
And we not far behinde.
Would I had time
To wonder at this laſt couple in hell.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: You are ſtaid for Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I come, pray God the buſineſſe
Hold me not from this ſport, I would not looſe it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Quinta.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: God give you joy, and make you live together
A happy paire.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: I do not doubt we ſhall.
There was never poore Gentleman had ſuch a ſodaine fortune,
I could thruſt my head betwixt 2. pales, & ſtrip me out of
My old skin like a Snake: will the gueſts come thou ſaidſt
Thou ſenteſt for to ſolemnize the Nuptials?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: They will, I looke for em ere this.

div.stage: Enter Julio, Jacamo, Fabritio, Franke, Clora.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: By your leave all.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: They'r here Sir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Eſpecially faire Lady
I aske your pardon, to whoſe marriage bed
I wiſh all good ſucceſſe, I have here brought you
Such gueſts as can diſcerne your happineſſe,
And beſt do know how to rejoyce at it;
For ſuch a fortune they themſelves have run,
The worthy Iacamo, and his faire Bride,
Noble Fabritio, whom this age of peace
Has not yet aught to love ought but the warrs,
And his true friends, this Lady who is but
A piece of me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Sir, you are welcome all,
Are they not Sir?

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Bring in ſome wine, ſome of the wine Lodwick the foole. Exit Fath.
Sent hither: who ever thou bid'ſt welcome ſhall finde it

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: An unexpected honour you have done
To our too haſty wedding.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Faith Madam, our weddings were as haſty as yours
We'ar glad to run up & downe any whether, to ſee where
We can get meat to our wedding.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: That Lodwick hath provided too, good Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I thought you Iulio, would not thus have ſtollen a marriage
Without acquainting your friends.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Why I did give thee incklings.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: If a marriage ſhould be thus ſlubberd up in a play, er'e almoſt
Any body had taken notice you were in love, the Spectators
Would take it to be but ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: This was the firſt, and I will never hide
An other ſecret from you.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Sir, yonder's your friend Lodwick, hide your ſelfe
And 'twill be the beſt ſport—

sp.speaker: Piſo
sp.l: Gentlemen, I pray you take no notice, I'm here.
The coxcomb Lodwick is coming in.

sp.speaker: Lodwick.
sp.l: Is that that Lady?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: That is my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: As I live ſhe's a faire one; what make al theſe heere?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: O Lord Sir ſhe is ſo peſterd—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Novv vvill the ſport be, it runnes right as Iulio told us

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Faire Lady health to you; ſome vvords I have, that
Require an utterance more private,
Then this place can afford.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I'le call my husband
All buſineſſe I heare vvith his eares novv.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good Madam no, bet I perceive your jeſt,
You have no husband, I am the very man
That vvalk'd the ſtreetes ſo comely.

sp.speaker: Lel
sp.l: Are you ſo?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes faith, vvhen Cupid firſt did prick your heart
I am not cruell, but the love began
I'th Street I'le ſatisfie i'th chamber fully.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: To aske a Madman vvhether he be mad
Were but an idle queſtion, if you be,
I do not ſpeake to you, but if you be not
Walke in the Streetes againe and there perhaps
I may dote on you, here I not endure you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good Madam ſtay do not you know this Ring?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Yes it vvas mine, I ſent it by my Man,
To change and ſo he did, it has a blemiſh,
And this he brought me for it; did you change it?
Are you a Goldſmith?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sure the world is mad,
Sirrah, did you not bring me this ring from your Lady?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yes ſurely Sir, did I, but your worſhip muſt ev'n beare with me;
For there was a miſtaking in it, and ſo: as I was
Saying to your worſhip, my Lady is now married.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Married? to whom?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: To your worſhips friend Piſo.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: S'death to Piſo?

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: within. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yes Sir I can aſſure you ſhe's maried to him, I ſaw't
With theſe gray eyes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why what a Rogue art thou then? thou haſt made
Me ſend in proviſion too.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: O a Gentleman ſhould not have ſuch fowle wordes in's mouth
But your Worſhips proviſion could not have come in at a fitter time;
Will it pleaſe you to taſt any of your owne wine?
It may be the Vintner has cozend you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Pox I am mad.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You have alwayes plots Sir, & ſee how they fall out.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: You had a plott upon me, how do you like this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I do not ſpeake to you.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Becauſe you dare not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: But I will have one of that old Rogues teeth ſett in this Ring

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Do'ſt not thou know that I can beate thee?
Doſt thou know it now? (diſcovers himſelfe)

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He beate me once indeed.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: And if you have forgot it, I can call a witneſſe.
Come forth Piſo—remember you it?

sp.speaker: Piſo
sp.l: Faith I do call to minde ſuch a matter.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: And if I cannot ſtill do't, you are young
And will aſſiſt your Father in law.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: My Father in law?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Your Father in law, as ſure as this is widow Lelia.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: How widow Lelia?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: I faith 'tis ſhe, Sonne.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, let my proviſion go, I am glad I
Have miſt the woman.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: Have you put a whore upon me?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: By heaven you do me wrong, I have a heart
As pure as any womans, and I meane
To keep it ſo for ever.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: There is no ſtarting now, Son, if you offer't
I can compell you, her eſtate is great,
But all made o're to me, before this match,
Yet if you uſe her kindly, as I ſweare
I thinke ſhe will deſerve, you ſhall enjoy it
During your life, all ſave ſome ſlender piece
I will reſerve for my own maintenance,
And if God bleſſe you with a childe by her,
It ſhall have all.

sp.speaker: Piſo.
sp.l: So I may have the meanes
I doe not much care what the woman is:
Come my ſweet heart, as long as I ſhall finde
Thy kiſſes ſweet, and thy meanes plentifull,
Let people talke their tongues out.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: They may talke
Of what is paſt, but all that is to come
Shall be without occaſions.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Shall we not make Piſo, and Lodwick friends?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Hang'em they dare not be Enemies, or if they be,
The danger is not greate, vvelcome Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fredrick.
sp.l: Firſt joy unto you all; and next I think
We ſhall haue vvarres.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Give me ſome vvine, I'le drinke to that.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I'le pledge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But I ſhall looſe you then.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Not a vvhit vvench; I'le teach thee preſently to be a Souldier

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Fabritios command, and yours are both reſtor'd

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Bring me foure glaſſes then.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You ſhall not drink 'em here, 'tis ſupper time,
And from my houſe no creature here ſhall ſtir,
Theſe three dayes, mirth ſhall flow as well as wine.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Content, within I'le tell you more at large
How much I am bound to all, but moſt to you,
Whoſe undeſerved liberality
Muſt not eſcape thus unrequited,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: 'Tis happinſſe to me, I did ſo well:
Of every noble action, the intent
Is to give worth reward, vice, puniſhment. Exeunt Om.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: TO pleaſe you with this Play, we feare will be
(So does the Author too) a myſtery
Somewhat above our Art; For all mens eyes,
Ears, faiths, and judgements, are not of one ſize.
For to ſay truth, and not to flatter ye,
This is nor Comody, nor Tragedy,
Nor Hiſtory, nor any thing that may
(Yet in a weeke) be made a perfect Play:
Yet thoſe that love to laugh, and thoſe that thinke
Twelve-pence goes farther this way then in drinke,
Or Damſels, if they marke the matter through,
May ſtumble on a fooliſh toy, or two
Will make 'em ſhew their teeth: pray, for my ſake
(That likely am your firſt man) doe not take
A diſtaſte before you feele it: for ye may
When this is hiſt to aſhes, have a Play.
And here, to out-hiſſe this; be patient then,
(My honour done) y'are welcome Gentlemen.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: IF you miſlike; (as you ſhall ever be
Your owne free Judges) this Play utterly,
For your owne Nobleneſſe, yet do not hiſſe,
But as you goe by, ſay it was amiſſe;
And we will mend: Chide vs, but let it be
Never in cold blood: O' my honeſty
(If I have any) this I'le ſay for all,
Our meaning was to pleaſe you ſtill, and ſhall.
